articles.headline: No Time to Run: Russian Missiles Hit Ukraine City Just After Sirens Sound
articles.snippet: More than 50 people were killed by two high-speed missiles that hit a military academy in the eastern city of Poltava, one of the most lethal Russian strikes in the war.
articles.abstract: More than 50 people were killed by two high-speed missiles that hit a military academy in the eastern city of Poltava, one of the most lethal Russian strikes in the war.
articles.lead_paragraph: Russian missiles struck a military academy in eastern Ukraine on Tuesday only minutes after air-raid alarms blared, killing more than 50 people, wounding many others and underscoring Moscow’s superior firepower in one of the war’s deadliest attacks. Ukraine’s president said a hospital also was hit.
articles.byline: By David Guttenfelder, Yurii Shyvala, Maria Varenikova and Marc Santora

articles.headline: Japan’s Era of ‘Free’ Mortgages Is Coming to an End
articles.snippet: Homeowners are gearing up to pay more on their loans as the Bank of Japan’s rate increases signal the end of decades of ultralow interest rates.
articles.abstract: Homeowners are gearing up to pay more on their loans as the Bank of Japan’s rate increases signal the end of decades of ultralow interest rates.
articles.lead_paragraph: For years, mortgages in Japan have been nearly cost free. Homeowners are now bracing for that to change.
articles.byline: By River Akira Davis and Kiuko Notoya

articles.headline: A Democracy With Everything but a Choice
articles.snippet: A new analysis of American elections finds that in half of all races for partisan offices, a candidate runs unopposed. Democrats are the biggest no-shows.
articles.abstract: A new analysis of American elections finds that in half of all races for partisan offices, a candidate runs unopposed. Democrats are the biggest no-shows.
articles.lead_paragraph: This November, voters in rural Perry County, Mo., will face a ballot with candidates for a bevy of local offices: state senator, state representative and circuit judge; two county commissioners, sheriff and many more.

articles.headline: Hounded From a Beauty Pageant in South Africa, Then Crowned in Nigeria
articles.snippet: A South African beauty pageant contestant with Nigerian heritage was forced to withdraw from the competition after her participation fueled anti-immigrant sentiments.
articles.abstract: A South African beauty pageant contestant with Nigerian heritage was forced to withdraw from the competition after her participation fueled anti-immigrant sentiments.
articles.lead_paragraph: On only her second visit to Nigeria, Chidimma Adetshina won that country’s Miss Universe beauty pageant.
articles.byline: By Lynsey Chutel and Nelson C.J

articles.headline: Iran Emerges as a Top Disinformation Threat in U.S. Presidential Race
articles.snippet: With a flurry of hacks and fake websites, Iran has intensified its efforts to discredit American democracy and possibly tip the race against former President Donald Trump.
articles.abstract: With a flurry of hacks and fake websites, Iran has intensified its efforts to discredit American democracy and possibly tip the race against former President Donald Trump.
articles.lead_paragraph: A website called Savannah Time describes itself as “your trusted source for conservative news and perspectives in the vibrant city of Savannah.” Another site, NioThinker, wants to be “your go-to destination for insightful, progressive news.” The online outlet Westland Sun appears to cater to Muslims in suburban Detroit.
articles.byline: By Steven Lee Myers, Tiffany Hsu and Farnaz Fassihi

articles.headline: U.S. Announces Plan to Counter Russian Influence Ahead of 2024 Election
articles.snippet: American spy agencies have assessed that the Kremlin favors former President Donald J. Trump, seeing him as skeptical of U.S. support for Ukraine.
articles.abstract: American spy agencies have assessed that the Kremlin favors former President Donald J. Trump, seeing him as skeptical of U.S. support for Ukraine.
articles.lead_paragraph: The United States on Wednesday announced a broad effort to push back on Russian influence campaigns in the 2024 election, as it tries to curb the Kremlin’s use of state-run media and fake news sites to sway American voters.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes, Glenn Thrush and Steven Lee Myers
